doc.title: Meituan Q2: Blood in the water
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/Bernstein/Meituan Q2 Blood in the waterMeituan Q2 Blood in the water_2025-08-28

processing_metadata.publication: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/Bernstein

passages.text: **Pain.** Meituan's Q2 results were a big miss of consensus expectations, bearing the scars of the ongoing food delivery competition in China. RMB91.8bn of group revenue grew 11.7%year on year, and missed Bloomberg consensus by 2.0%. RMB2.8bn of adjusted EBITDA was 81.5% lower year on year. Core Local Commerce operating profit (RMB3.7bn) was 75.6% lower year on year, and was 72.4%/RMB9.8bn lower versus Q1. Based on Meituan commentary around the quarter, we estimated minimal Food Delivery revenue growth in Q2.We put In-store, Hotel & Travel (IHT) revenue growth in the mid-teens range...versus a low-thirties percentage operating margin.

**Is the spend irrational if you're winning?** Q2 is seasonally a higher quarter for food delivery profits: we think the sequential comparison with Q1 implied that the ongoing food delivery competition cost Meituan c. RMB10-12bn in incremental spend in Q2. Meituan management made multiple references to "irrational" competition, but the evidence from this quarter arguably adds to peers' resolve to keep upping the ante. A repeat of the July 5 debacle is probably unlikely, when the platforms tried very publicly to run up order volume records. But we doubt government regulators mind that a trio of large Internet platforms are subsidising consumers on its behalf. Alibaba has already guided to higher spend in Q3; we'd guess they sound more on the front foot when reporting on Friday.

**Core Local Commerce losses in Q3... and beyond.** Guidance for "substantial" Core Local Commerce losses in Q3 will likely come as a shock to the market. Mechanically it implies large downward revisions far earnings estimates in 2025, but likely also 2026. Zooming out, with the ongoing subsidy battle causing large shifts in market share and rider network density, we think it's safe to say that (1) e-commerce and food delivery competition has fully converged, and (2) Meituan's industry structure has structurally worsened. Balance sheet strength wins in a war of attrition, and Meituan now looks on the back foot. The company's ongoing overseas investments look increasingly like a distracting sideshow.
**Investment Implications**
**We rate Meituan Market-Perform (PT HK$95).**

Meituan's Q2 2025 results were very weak, showing the impact of ongoing food delivery competition in China. Group and Core Local Commerce revenues of RMB91.8bn and RMB65.3bn grew \(11.7\%\) and \(7.7\%\) year on year, both a few percent lower than our estimates and Bloomberg consensus. Gross profit of RMB30.4bn declined \(10.3\%\) year on year, and implied 810bps of year on year gross margin erosion. Core Local Commerce operating profit of RMB3.7bn fell \(75.6\%\) year on year, and \(72.4\%\) versus Q1. New Initiatives loss of RMB1.9bn was lower than we and the street had modelled (RMB2.1bn and RMB2.4bn). Meituan adjusted EBITDA at the group level reached RMB2.8bn, \(81.5\%\) lower year on year, and significantly lower than we and the street had modelled. Advertising revenues within Core Local Commerce reached RMB13.5bn, \(10.5\%\) higher year on year. Commission revenue grew \(12.9\%\) .

Based on management commentary over the quarter, we estimate that food delivery volume and GTV grew low- teens and high- single digits respectively in Q2... while high incentives grew very minimally, and dropped down to a slight operating loss for the quarter. We estimate IHT revenue grew in the \(15\%\) range last quarter, while operating margin was lower quarter on quarter. Within the New Initiatives segment, Meituan Select was said to have contributed c. RMB1.6bn of loss.
Our latest price target for Meituan is based on a \(1.3\times 2027\mathrm{EP}\) s multiple, compared with lower revenue estimates.

Taking a step back, RMB10- 12bn of burn through most of two months in Q2 likely explains Meituan's guidance for "substantial Core Local Commerce losses in Q3. Management speaking around the quarter attributed most of the RMB7bn sequential increase in marketing spend to food delivery incentives. Note also that Meituan's user incentives recorded contra revenue are typically double of that booked in marketing spend... suggesting the total quarter on quarter increase in marketing spend was closer to RMB15bn. The fact Meituan lost just as much as JD in Q2 asks awkward questions on the value of its customer loyalty, and the company's ability to outlast the competition. Sequential increases in rider costs were explained as necessary spend to maintain order network density and delivery times... and felt indicative of the network effects in Meituan's food delivery business working in reverse, in the face of competitive pressure.

In the orange corner, Alibaba has already signalled higher spend in Q3 than Q2, and we'd guess the company will have been encouraged by the impact its efforts are having on Meituan... even if (as Meituan management argue, probably rightly) it currently loses significantly higher amounts per order. On the analyst call, Meituan management tried to project a sense of business as usual, and keep the focus on in- house developments, things the company is building. Speaking around the quarter though they did also acknowledge that competitive intensity in food delivery will remain high in the next "few quarters". For what it's worth, August was said to have brought a slight moderation in competitive intensity versus July, but the company declined to make comparisons with June, when Alibaba entering the competitive fray led to Meituan's food delivery unit profit turning negative. The fact Meituan is expanding membership benefits in its IHT business as a way to fight back competitively probably means margins here will remain structurally lower too.

The speed at which Meituan's competitive position has eroded in recent months has been eye- opening. Structurally, we see parallels between what's happening in food delivery right now and Alibaba's loss of market dominance in 2021. A war of attrition decided on the basis of balance sheet strength would render Meituan's 2026 earnings impossible to forecast. In the spirit of compiling projections for the sake of debate we've cut our estimates for Meituan substantially, and now model group- level losses in 2025 and 2026. Notably though even competitive normalisation and an eventual return to 2021- 2022 levels of food delivery profitability (i.e. before Alibaba last gave up on food delivery competition) implies significant downside to Meituan's outer year estimates, and implied fair values for its shares.
Group revenue. Meituan revenue of RMB91.8bn was \(+11.7\%\) year- on- year, missing our estimate (RMB95.1bn) and Bloomberg consensus on RMB93.7bn.
Core Local Commerce revenue. Core Local Commerce revenue of RMB65.3bn was \(+7.7\%\) year-on-year, missing our estimate on RMB69.6bn and Bloomberg consensus on RMB67.5bn.
Core Local Commerce operating profit. Core Local Commerce operating profit of RMB3.7bn was \(75.6\%\) lower year-on-year, missing our estimate (RMB12.1bn) and Bloomberg consensus on RMB12.0bn.

Gross profit. RMB30.4bn of group gross profit was \(10.3\%\) lower year-on-year, and implied a \(33.1\%\) margin (Q2 2024: \(41.2\%\) ). We had estimated RMB38.7bn (40.7% margin), while consensus was lower at RMB36.1bn (38.5% margin).
Adjusted net profit. RMB1.5bn of non-GAAP net profit was \(89.0\%\) lower year-on-year, missing our estimate on RMB9.4bn and consensus (RMB9.9bn).
Exhibit 1 shows a summary of Meituan's Q2 earnings compared with our estimates and consensus. Exhibit 2 shows comparisons on a segment basis.
EXHIBIT 1: Meituan: Results summary

We've updated our estimates for Meituan to reflect Q2 reporting, and our discussions with the company around the quarter. Our estimates for Meituan are substantially lower than prior levels to reflect food delivery losses in Q3 and Q4. We've modelled for a moderation in competitive intensity in 2026, though this should probably be considered under review, in the context of rapidly
evolving competitive shifts on the ground.

Exhibit 3 shows a summary of our estimate changes for Meituan. The considerable uncertainty around Meituan's go- forward profits means we've shifted to a price- to- sales multiple to value its businesses. Our latest price target for Meituan implies 1.3x 2026E PS. Intellectually, the exact PS multiple we choose (e.g. 1.1x vs. 1.3x PS) is probably immaterial until there is greater clarity around Meituan's competitive outlook - even though mathematically the delta makes a big difference for implied valuations.
Tactically we'd expect Meituan's shares to react negatively to this print, though the fact positioning has become very negative likely limits realistic downside at least in the very near- term.
EXHIBIT 3: Meituan: summary of estimate changes
Source: Corporate reports, Bloomberg, Bernstein estimates and analysis.

On April 1, 2024, Société Générale (SG) and AllianceBernstein, LP. (AB) completed a transaction that created a new joint venture in which their respective cash equities and research businesses operate in a new business combination. Although their respective ownership percentages in the joint venture differ between North America and the rest of the world, the creation, production and publication of research is handled collaboratively on a global basis across the two research brands, "Bernstein" and "Autonomous". Unless specifically noted otherwise, for purposes of these disclosures, references to Bernstein's "affiliates" relate to both SG and AB and their respective affiliates.
We value Meituan at HK\$95 per share, on a 1.3x 2026E PS multiple.

The main upside risks associated with significantly reduced competition in the food delivery sector, changes of overseas strategy resulting in lower than expected international losses, and much faster revenue and profit growths for Instashopping.

The main downside risks associated with our price target for Meituan include macroeconomic risks (e.g. credit, retail consumption), fluctuations in user engagement with its platforms, food delivery unit economics - including average order value, monetisation rate, rider costs, and operating expenses, competition with rival internet platforms (e.g. Ele.me, Trip.com), regulatory risks - for example related to China's anti- monopoly regulations, and losses in the company's new businesses (e.g. community e- commerce).

The Bernstein brand rates stocks based on forecasts of relative performance for the next 12 months versus the S&P 500 for stocks listed on the U.S. and Canadian exchanges, versus the Bloomberg Europe Developed Markets Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index (EDM) for stocks listed on the European exchanges and emerging markets exchanges outside of the Asia Pacific region, versus the Bloomberg Japan Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index USD (JP) for stocks listed on the Japanese exchanges, and versus the Bloomberg Asia ex- Japan Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index (ASIAX) for stocks listed on the Asian (ex- Japan) exchanges - unless otherwise specified.
The Bernstein brand has three categories of ratings:

- Outperform: Stock will outpace the market index by more than 15 pp- Market-Perform: Stock will perform in line with the market index to within +/-15 pp- Underperform: Stock will trail the performance of the market index by more than 15 pp
